docTitle.titlePart:
Highly Flexible UV-Vis Radiation Source and Novel Detection Schemes
for Spectrophotometric HPLC Detection

byline.docAuthor:
Karsten G. Kraiczek,
*,, R. Bonjour,
Y. Salvadé,
and Roland Zengerle

front.div:
As an example, Figure S1 shows the loss in optical output power over time of 265 nm DUV LEDs at
three different forward currents 5 mA, 10 mA and 20 mA. The emitting area for all LEDs is the same
and approximately 150 µm x 250 µm. The objective of the experiment was to determine the
degradation rate over time and the temperature coefficient of the optical output power for an aging
DUV LED. The ambient temperature was recorded in each degradation experiment and fluctuated at a
maximum of ±5°C and around an average of 25°C. The temperature coefficient ß for the LEDs optical
output power was calculated by minimizing the temperature induced effects on the degradation curve.
The temperature coefficient is a function of the forward current and is unfortunately relative large but
was found to be constant over the entire lifetime of the DUV LED. The table in Figure S1 summarizes
the lifetime performance data of the 265 nm DUV LEDs tested.
Figure S1: Degradation behavior of '265 nm' DUV LEDs at different forward currents. Ambient temperature = 25°C
±5°C. Lifetime performance data in table are calculated from 'smoothened' curves which are corrected for temperature
effects. A degradation rate of -1 %/h corresponds to a detector drift of +4.3 mAU/h.
The 50% lifetime definition seems to be of limited value for DUV LEDs because their useful lifetime
begins at about this time with acceptable drift performance and still sufficient light output. All DUV
